messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:

>>>Why work on it if the testing framework can do it for you?
>>>
>>>Without dependent methods: "10 FAILURES".
>>>
>>>With dependent methods: "1 FAILURE, 9 SKIPS".
>>>
>>>I know which result I prefer :-)
>>>
>>>
>>They both say the same thing to me: I've got something that, if it is
>>broken, affects lots of tests.
>>
>>
>Not quite, because "10 FAILURES" might mean that there are really ten broken
>tests, or that there is one broken and nine that failed because that first
>one failed. Or the break down could be 2/8. Or 3/7. Or... you get the
>idea.
>
>Over the years, I have learned to mistrust the results that JUnit gives me
>for that reaon. I read "10 FAILURES" and deep inside, I know that "nah,
>it's not really ten failures".
>
>And it's so easy for the testing framework to provide accurate reports if it
>gets a little help from the developer...
>
>
Cedric, but 2 + 2 still going to be 4 and you still will have to
investigate why above 10 cases failed... It is not that convincing,
really, but may add an additional confusion, like why those 9 tests were
skipped and if that single failure in fact has any impact on any of 9
skipped cases.
With dependent tests we don't really talk about isolated unit tests
but rather about some integration tests when overall code coverage
within given test case is going down when number of layers of the
non-directly tested code is increasing. So, it could be pretty much a
bad smell...
BTW, for those haven't seen it yet, there is a nice rule enforcement
tool for things like that called Ashcroft -
http://docs.codehaus.org/display/ASH/Home I believe it would nicely
work with TestNG too. ;-)

regards,
Eugene
